“Through textile excavation I unpick inherited silks, severing ancestral seams to re-stitch queer futures. Each fray maps displacement: Kolkata couture collides with East-End sweat, bindis become disco sequins, the sari re-draped as protest banner. My loom samples diaspora static—radio chatter, airport announcements, auntie gossip—then jacquard-weaves it into iridescent armour that claps back at empire while cradling the wearer like immigrant prayer. Scent is embedded: cardamom, boot polish, chlorine of municipal pools where brown kids learnt to float. Garments carry barcoded borders that scan as error 404—nation not found. Viewers are asked to unpick a single gold thread; the slow unravelling performs undocumented departure. What survives is a fringe that trembles between loss and touchdown, a wearable hyphen that refuses full stop.”

**[Artist Name]’s work excavates inherited textiles, unraveling ancestral seams to reweave queer futures.**  Kolkata couture clashes with East-End grit, bindis become disco sequins, saris transform into protest banners.  These are not garments of nostalgia, but weapons of becoming.

Scents of cardamom, boot polish, and chlorine linger, evoking immigrant memory: the spice of home, the grime of survival, the chlorine tang of public pools where brown kids learned to float.

These are not passive objects, but active sites of resistance. Each garment bears a barcoded border, a visual glitch in the system, a refusal to be categorized. Viewers are invited to unpick a single gold thread, to experience the slow unraveling of identity, the delicate balance between loss and arrival. What remains is a fringe that trembles, a wearable hyphen refusing full stop.

[Artist Name]’s work is a testament to the resilience of the diaspora, a vibrant tapestry woven from the threads of history, memory, and defiance.
